Investigate the implications of the Fourier transform \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} u(x, t)e^{-i\\omega x}dx \\) applied to this model.

If the initial heat distribution \\( u(x, 0) \\) is transformed by \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, 0) \\) without further intervention, will the heat distribution at time T, transformed as \\( \\hat{u}(\\omega, T) \\), follow the same rules regulated by \\( \\frac{\\partial \\hat{u}}{\\partial t} = -k\\omega^2\\hat{u} \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of the heat equation maintains its form under the transform due to the linearity of the differential equation and Fourier operation. The transformation predicts the behavior of the frequency components of the heat equation, confirming consistency across transformations.
